text: What I mean is, now this is assuming that we are not using a VIX future or a volatility ETP to express our trade forecast on volatility. So we all know that, yeah, we wish that as retail anyway, that we could trade a variant swap or OTC product to give us a more direct exposure to what we're trying to predict. But we can't. And so we have to use options and options are messy. Options are path dependent. And so when you are trading, let's say a straddle with five days to go on the SPX, you need to understand that that upside is most likely in most cases going to be what hurts you as opposed to what everybody gets told through media and through pundits and through macroeconomic podcasts and personalities. Oh, it's the end of the world, the downside, the downside. In my experience, it is the upside. So much. So over the past 10 years that I've gotten to the point where I almost need a full smile on the SPX in order to sell the upside. And there are times where that happens, right? So this time last year, we saw the SPX smirk or skew turn into a smile. That's when you want to sell like an iron condor, for me, a tight iron condor, but like a condor or a strangle or something like that, where you're actually getting compensated on the upside. But on most times, even if you're into technical analysis or something like that. And you're in situations where you're like, oh, this may look bearish. Somehow, some way that call is going to be threatened. That upside is going to be threatened. So you really have to pay close attention to the price that you're selling something for. Because otherwise, the upside is what will take you out. I've seen it happen. In fact, two weeks ago, I tweeted that up because I could tell that it was one of those days where we went down and we went down and we ended up down like close to 2% or something like that. And I'm like, these are the exact times where people get caught. They try to find a way to sell something like an iron condor, a strangle or something. And they're just selling a condor or selling a strangle or something. And then all of a sudden, the SPX will just rip your head off. And those calls will be deep in the money, and you'll lose. And that happens so many times, Corey. You'd be amazed at the predictability of it. It happens a lot. All the time. To the point where... Like I said, I would like for the Smirk to turn into a smile before I actually sell upside.
